Abstract: This paper critically examines the widespread practice of partialing in psychological research, particularly its use in refining scores and inferences about psychological constructs. We argue that while partialing is often employed to enhance construct validity, it may inadvertently introduce methodological and interpretative issues. Through a comprehensive review of literature and statistical analyses, we demonstrate how residualized variables and statistical control can lead to misleading conclusions about the nature and relationships of psychological constructs. We explore the unintended consequences of semipartial effects on measurement integrity and theoretical interpretations. Our findings suggest that partialing, when applied uncritically, may constitute a questionable measurement practice that undermines rather than enhances construct validity. We propose guidelines for researchers to critically evaluate the appropriateness of partialing in their studies and offer alternative approaches to address the underlying concerns that motivate its use. This work contributes to ongoing discussions about measurement practices in psychological research and their implications for scientific rigor and reproducibility.
